questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

 

The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) is characterized by the excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the posterior pituitary gland or another source. This excessive release results in water retention and dilutional hyponatremia.

 

Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L: This option is incorrect. In SIADH, urinary sodium is typically high, usually greater than 40 mEq/L, due to the body's inability to excrete water appropriately, which leads to concentrated urine with high sodium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum sodium <135 mEq/L: This option is correct as SIADH commonly presents with hyponatremia (low serum sodium levels) due to the dilution of blood sodium by the retained water.


Option C. Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg: This option is correct. In SIADH, urine osmolality is typically high because the kidneys are concentrating the urine inappropriately due to the persistent effect of ADH.

 

Option D. Patient can be clinically euvolemic: This option is correct. Patients with SIADH often appear clinically euvolemic (normal body fluid volume), as the retained water is distributed evenly throughout the body without significant signs of fluid overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key fact to remember is that in SIADH, patients have high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L) due to the body's inability to excrete water properly, leading to concentrated urine.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought to OPD with complaint of painless lump in left knee. X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteochondroma

 

OSTEOCHONDROMA

 

  • Osteochondroma is the commonest benign “tumour” of the bone.
  • It is a developmental malformation and not a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate.
  • It is thought to originate within the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodule.
  • X-ray shows an osseous outgrowth arising from the medial aspect of the distal femur and directed upwards (away from the joint), its cortex appears continuous with that of the femur.
  • Osteochondroma shows a bone with cartilage cap, a result of development malformation.
  • An osseus outgrowth grows away from bone and grows till skeletal maturity.
  • Many of these lesions cause no symptoms and are discovered incidentally.
  • Pain may be present due to bursitis or malignant transformation, fracture through stalk or pedunculated (narrow based) lesion, sarcomatous change and Impingement of neighboring structure, e.g. nerve, vessel, etc.
  • The physical finding usually is a palpable mass.
  • Treatment: en bloc resection – extra-periosteal resection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enchondroma is a benign tumor of short tubular bones of the hand. They are the chondromas that usually arise in the medullary canal. They are treated with extended curettage.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Osteoclastoma is located at the epiphysis. The most common location is distal femur, followed by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. Patient presents with swelling and vague pain. Radiographic examination reveals bony swelling, eccentrically located at the end of the bone and soap bubble appearance on X-ray. Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex, however, intraarticular extension is rare as the subchondral bone usually remains intact. Treatment is done by extended curettage by PMMA or phenol or liquid nitrogen and bone grafting – the procedure of choice. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteochondromas are developmental malformations rather than true neoplasms that are usually painless.
  • The pain can be due to bursitis (most common).
  • The physical finding is usually a palpable mass.

questions.text: A 53-year-old gentleman presents with chest pain which is happening at rest. Pain is persistent for 3-5 minutes and he is having recurrent pain over the last 48 hours and he used 3 puffs of GTN to relieve his pain. His current medications include GTN PRN, Atorvastatin 20mg HS, Metoprolol 50mg BID, and Aspirin 75mg OD. His troponin was negative and ECG showed LVH with flattening of the ST segment. What is the most appropriate next step in management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Start enoxaparin 1mg/kg s.c BD

 

The patient is presenting with symptoms suggestive of unstable angina, given the recurrent chest pain at rest and ECG changes (left ventricular hypertrophy with ST segment flattening). Despite the negative troponin, which rules out myocardial infarction, the clinical scenario points to a high risk of acute coronary syndrome (ACS).

 

For high-risk ACS, especially in a patient already on medications for coronary artery disease (CAD) like aspirin, atorvastatin, and metoprolol, initiating anticoagulation therapy is crucial to prevent thrombus formation and progression to myocardial infarction. Enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin, is recommended at a therapeutic dose of 1 mg/kg subcutaneously twice a day to achieve effective anticoagulation in this setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Add long-acting nitrate: While long-acting nitrates can help with angina symptoms, they are not the primary treatment for acute management in this scenario. The priority is to stabilize the patient and prevent further thrombotic events.

 

Option B. Increase metoprolol dose to 100mg BID: Increasing the dose of metoprolol may help with angina control, but it does not address the underlying risk of thrombus formation and is not the immediate next step in managing high-risk unstable angina.

 

Option C. Add clopidogrel 75mg OD: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent that is beneficial in ACS, but in this acute setting, starting anticoagulation with enoxaparin takes precedence to prevent thrombus formation. Clopidogrel can be added as part of dual antiplatelet therapy later on.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with high-risk unstable angina, especially those with recurrent chest pain at rest and ECG changes, initiating therapeutic anticoagulation with enoxaparin is a critical step in the acute management to prevent thrombus formation and progression to myocardial infarction.

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by which dermatome ? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. T10

 

The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

 

The T10 dermatome is significant because it corresponds to the umbilical region. Often, when clinicians check for sensation around the umbilicus, they are assessing the integrity of the T10 spinal nerve. This dermatome covers the region around the umbilicus, extending a bit below it.

 

Dermatomes are specific areas of skin that are supplied by sensory nerves originating from a single spinal nerve root. Each segment of the spinal cord gives rise to a pair (left and right) of spinal nerves, and each of these spinal nerves carries sensory information from a distinct region of the body to the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T8: The T8 dermatome primarily covers the area just above the level of the umbilicus. If you were to draw a horizontal line around the trunk at the level of the umbilicus, this would approximate the center of the T8 dermatomal distribution.

 

Option B. T9: The T9 dermatome is situated just below the T8 level and above T10. It covers the region between the umbilicus and the midline of the abdomen, approximately at the level where the xiphoid process (the small cartilaginous extension at the lower end of the sternum) ends.

 

Option D. T11: The T11 dermatome covers an area of the anterior trunk below the T10 level but above the groin. It is positioned just before the first lumbar dermatome starts, and it sits above the inguinal ligament, which is a band running from the pubic tubercle to the anterior superior iliac spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows:

choices.text: ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation
If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done
Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness which lasted for a few seconds followed by a regain of full consciousness. There were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this scenario? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation

 

An electrocardiogram (ECG) is crucial in the initial evaluation of a patient presenting with syncope, particularly to rule out cardiac causes such as atrial fibrillation, which can lead to episodic reductions in cardiac output and cerebral perfusion. Atrial fibrillation, a common arrhythmia in the elderly, can cause transient episodes of dizziness and loss of consciousness due to irregular and often rapid heart rate leading to ineffective heart pumping.

 

Note - In an elderly w/ first episode of syncope detailed history, clinical exam (cardiac, postural BP, neuro exam), basic investigations (ECG, +/- ECHO) is required

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done: While a CT scan might be considered if there is suspicion of a neurological cause after a thorough clinical evaluation, it is not automatically the next step following a normal ECG, especially in the absence of neurological symptoms or signs suggestive of structural brain disease.

 

Option C. Tilt-table testing: This is generally reserved for cases where recurrent unexplained episodes of syncope occur, particularly when a vasovagal or orthostatic cause is suspected, not typically used after a first episode unless specific indications are present.

 

Option D. Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms: Vestibular neuritis can cause severe vertigo and imbalance but typically does not cause loss of consciousness, making it less likely in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients presenting with an acute onset of dizziness and syncope, an ECG is an essential first step to rule out arrhythmic causes such as atrial fibrillation. Additional diagnostic steps should be guided by the findings of the initial evaluation and specific clinical indicators.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Atrial fibrillation/Chap 251

questions.text: Following is the x-ray of an 18-year-old boy who complains of fever, pain in the lower limb, local rise of temperature, and tenderness in the area shown. On investigation, he has increased ESR. What can be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ewing's sarcoma

 

  • This case presents a teenager (18-year-old) with symptoms of fever, pain, local rise in temperature, and tenderness in the lower limb, along with increased ESR are suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Radiological features:
    • The first image shows a layered periosteal reaction (onion-skin appearance), which is characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma.
    • The second and third images show a permeative pattern of bone destruction with a soft tissue mass, another hallmark of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Ewing's sarcoma typically affects children and adolescents (common in ages 10–20).
  • Symptoms include localized pain, swelling, fever, and elevated ESR, often mimicking infection like osteomyelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Germ cell tumor: Germ cell tumors typically arise in the reproductive organs (testes or ovaries) or occasionally outside these locations (extragonadal). It is not typically a primary bone tumor and doesn't fit the radiographic pattern.

 

Option B. Osteomyelitis: Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone and can cause fever, pain, and elevated ESR, mimicking the symptoms of this case. However, osteomyelitis is more likely to show a solid periosteal reaction or sequestra on x-ray. Osteomyelitis may look similar clinically but rarely shows onion-skin periosteal reaction.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is another malignant bone tumor that commonly presents with a sunburst appearance and Codman’s triangle on x-ray. However, osteosarcoma typically arises in the metaphysis (the wide part at the ends of bones), particularly in the distal femur or proximal tibia, rather than the diaphysis. It usually presents with pain and swelling but not systemic signs like fever and high ESR to this extent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ewing’s sarcoma typically presents in the diaphysis of long bones in children and adolescents, with a onion skin periosteal reaction seen on x-ray.

questions.text: What is an infrequent yet highly serious adverse outcome of clozapine that necessitates consistent monitoring?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Agranulocytosis

 

CLOZAPINE

 

  • Treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS)- Lack of response to at least two different antipsychotics, including at least one second-generation antipsychotic, given in adequate dosage and for an adequate duration (at least 4-6 weeks).
  • Clozapine is the drug of choice (DOC) in TRS.
  • Unique mechanism of action- More affinity for D4 than D2, hence causes minimal EPS.
  • Antipsychotic that causes max weight gain.
  • Clozapine is the only antipsychotic with antisuicide property.

 

Side effects of clozapine

 

  • Life-threatening: Agranulocytosis (idiosyncratic), myocarditis (idiosyncratic), seizures (dose-dependent)
  • Sedation (most common), sialorrhea
  • Syncope, hypotension, tachycardia, nausea, vomiting
  • Weight gain, anticholinergic side effects
  • Due to the possibility of agranulocytosis, when a patient is on clozapine, ANC and TLC monitoring is required.
  • The regime of monitoring-
    • First 6 months- Once a week
    • Next 6 months- Once in two weeks
    • After 1 year- Once in four weeks, till clozapine is continued 
  • Stop clozapine, if WBC < 3000/dl or ANC < 1500/dl
  • Contraindications for clozapine use
    • WBC < 3500/dl
    • History of agranulocytosis on clozapine
    • Use of other bone marrow suppressants like carbamazepine

questions.text: Sudden loss of vision without fundal glow without history of trauma is caused by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitreous hemorrhage

 

Vitreous hemorrhage is characterized by sudden loss of vision and absence of fundal glow without a history of trauma. This occurs because blood in the vitreous cavity blocks light from reaching the retina, preventing visualization of the fundus and causing vision loss. The sudden onset and lack of fundal glow are key diagnostic features of vitreous hemorrhage.

 

 

Causes of Vitreous hemorrhage:

 

  • Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR)
  • Eales Disease
  • Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO)
  • Post trauma

 

Treatment:

 

  • Initial Step: Patients should maintain a propped-up position to help settle the blood within the eye.
  • Natural Resolution: Wait for the hemorrhage to clear up spontaneously, as many cases resolve without intervention.
  • Surgical Treatment: If the hemorrhage does not resolve naturally and vision remains impaired, a vitrectomy may be performed. This surgery involves removing the blood-filled vitreous and replacing it with a saline solution to restore the eye's shape and function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute congestive glaucoma: While this can cause sudden vision loss, it typically doesn't result in complete loss of fundal glow. The fundus may appear hazy due to corneal edema, but it's usually still visible to some extent.

 

Option C. Optic atrophy: This condition leads to gradual vision loss rather than sudden loss. Moreover, the fundus and optic disc would still be visible during examination, allowing for clear visualization of the atrophied optic nerve.

 

Option D. Acute anterior uveitis: This primarily affects the front part of the eye and doesn't typically cause sudden, severe vision loss or loss of fundal glow unless there are extensive inflammatory membranes in the pupillary area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sudden loss of vision combined with absence of fundal glow, without a history of trauma, is highly characteristic of vitreous hemorrhage. This condition requires prompt evaluation to determine the underlying cause, which could include proliferative diabetic retinopathy, Eales disease, central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), or other vascular abnormalities of the retina

questions.text: Mr. Seth recently underwent surgery to remove a parathyroid gland due to hyperparathyroidism. The surgeon informed the patient that one or more of the parathyroid glands may be transferred to another location during the surgery to protect them or due to their location. The parathyroid is commonly transferred to? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Brachioradialis

 

Explanation:

 

The most common site for the relocation of the parathyroid gland(s) is in the forearm muscle, specifically the nondominant side brachioradialis. Transplantation to this location provides several advantages:

  • Accessibility: The forearm location is easily accessible for potential future surgical interventions if necessary.
  • Monitoring: This location allows for straightforward monitoring of parathyroid function using simple clinical tests.
  • Functionality: The transplanted gland(s) will continue to produce parathyroid hormone normally, aiding in the regulation of calcium levels in the body.
  • Ease of Removal: If there is disease recurrence after surgery, the forearm location facilitates easy removal.
  • Typically, a total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted in a type of heterotopic transplant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triceps: Triceps is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation due to less accessibility and monitoring challenges compared to the brachioradialis.

 

Option B. Biceps: Biceps is also not commonly used for parathyroid transplantation because it does not offer the same ease of access and monitoring advantages as the brachioradialis.

 

Option C. Sartorius: Sartorius is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation. The forearm muscle (brachioradialis) is favored for its convenience and monitoring benefits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The brachioradialis muscle in the forearm is the most common site for parathyroid gland relocation during surgery due to its ease of access, convenient monitoring, and straightforward removal if needed.

choices.text: Includes breathing, movements, tone, and Amniotic fluid volume
Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH
Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages
Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia

questions.text: All are true about biophysical profile (BPP) except? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages

 

Explanation:

 

  • BPP score is not inconsistent with fetal pH, but has a direct linear relationship with fetal pH and thus can be used to predict fetal acidemia.
  • BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency.
  • It consists of five components/ variables and the observations are made in a 30 minutes time period.
  • The Biophysical Profile has 5 components and is scored using Manning score
    • NST
    • Amniotic Fluid Volume
    • Fetal movement
    • Fetal Tone
    • Fetal Breathing

   

 

  • A low Manning score correlates with fetal hypoxia
  • Narcotics and sedatives can significantly lower the score
  • A BPP score of 0 was almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia, whereas a normal score of 8 or 10 was associated with normal pH.
  • An equivocal test result—a score of 6—was a poor predictor of an abnormal outcome. A drop in the BPP score from 2 or 4 down to 0 more accurately predicted an abnormal fetal outcome.
  • Overall, BPP scores provided poor sensitivity to predict cord blood pH
  • The Modified BPP has 2 components
    • NST
    • AFI

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Includes breathing, movements, tone, and Amniotic fluid volume: This statement is true. The BPP includes assessments of fetal breathing, movements, tone, and the Amniotic fluid volume as part of its evaluation.

 

Option B. Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH: This statement is true. The BPP score helps predict fetal outcome and provides an indication of fetal pH, reflecting the level of fetal distress.

 

Option D. Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia: This statement is true. A BPP score of less than 4 correlates with a fetal pH <7.2, and a score of 0 is almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Biophysical Profile (BPP) provides a consistent prediction of fetal pH and outcome, with a lower score correlating with increased risk of fetal acidemia.

 

Ref: Page no 999, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to OPD with proptosis of left eye. On investigation, it was found to be a Desmin positive tumour. What can be the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma

 

Given clinical scenario and tumor showing Desmin positive, points to a diagnosis of Embryonal Rhabdomyosarcoma.

 

Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma presents as a soft gray infiltrative mass. The tumor cells mimic skeletal muscle at various stages of differentiation and consist of sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells. Rhabdomyoblasts with straplike cytoplasm and visible cross-striations may be present.

 

Sarcoma botryoides is a variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma that develops in the walls of hollow viscera such as the urinary bladder and vagina.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is typically positive for CD99 and is more commonly found in bone or soft tissue, not usually associated with Desmin positivity.

 

Option C. Leukemia: Leukemia cells are positive for CD45 (leukocyte common antigen) and are not associated with Desmin positivity or presenting as a soft tissue mass with proptosis.

 

Option D. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina, typically presenting with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and is associated with RB1 gene mutations. It is not associated with Desmin positivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, a common pediatric soft tissue sarcoma, is typically Desmin-positive and can present with proptosis, particularly when it arises in the orbit.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 2435-2437

questions.text: The marked structure secretes which hormone? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adrenaline

 

The marked structure in the provided histological image is the adrenal medulla. The adrenal medulla is the innermost part of the adrenal gland and is responsible for the secretion of catecholamines, primarily adrenaline (epinephrine) and norepinephrine. These hormones are crucial for the "fight or flight" response, increasing heart rate, blood pressure, and energy availability.

 

 

 

 

In the adrenal gland, there are three distinct zones in the cortex, each responsible for secreting different hormones:

 

  1. Zona glomerulosa (outermost): Secretes mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone, which regulate sodium and potassium balance.
  2. Zona fasciculata (middle): Secretes glucocorticoids, primarily cortisol, which are involved in glucose metabolism, immune response, and stress response.
  3. Zona reticularis (innermost cortex layer): Secretes androgens, which are sex hormones.

 

The adrenal medulla, which lies beneath these cortical layers, contains chromaffin cells that secrete adrenaline. This area is marked in the image, making adrenaline the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Androgen: Androgens are secreted by the zona reticularis of the adrenal cortex.

 

Option C. Glucocorticoid: Glucocorticoids, such as cortisol, are secreted by the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex.

 

Option D. Mineralocorticoid: Mineralocorticoids, such as aldosterone, are secreted by the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The adrenal medulla, the innermost part of the adrenal gland, is responsible for secreting adrenaline, a hormone essential for the body's acute stress response.

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary lymphoid organ? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thymus

 

Primary lymphoid organs are those where lymphocytes, such as T cells and B cells, develop and mature. The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ responsible for the maturation of T cells. It provides an environment for precursor cells to develop into mature T lymphocytes, which are essential for adaptive immunity. The thymus plays a critical role in establishing central tolerance, ensuring that T cells that react against self-antigens are eliminated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spleen: The spleen is a secondary lymphoid organ where immune responses are initiated. It filters the blood and houses immune cells but is not involved in the maturation of lymphocytes.

 

Option B. Lymph node: Lymph nodes are secondary lymphoid organs. They filter lymphatic fluid and serve as sites where immune responses are initiated but do not participate in the initial development or maturation of lymphocytes.

 

Option D. Tonsils: Tonsils are also considered secondary lymphoid organs. They play a role in the immune response to pathogens entering through the mouth or nose but are not involved in lymphocyte maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ where T cells mature, playing a crucial role in the development of the immune system.

 

Spleen, lymph node and tonsils are considered as secondary lymphoid organs

 

Bone marrow has been considered as an example of both a primary as well as a secondary lymphoid organ.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with symptoms of acute bacterial prostatitis, including fever, chills, dysuria, and perineal pain. A urine sample is taken, and a culture is performed, which reveals the presence of a common organism associated with acute bacterial prostatitis. Identify the organism?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. E. coli

 

Escherichia coli, commonly known as E. coli, is a gram-negative bacillus and is part of the normal flora of the gastrointestinal tract. E. coli is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis, accounting for the vast majority of cases. It's also a very common cause of urinary tract infections in general.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterococcus: Enterococcus species are gram-positive cocci that are part of the normal gut flora. They are an infrequent cause of acute bacterial prostatitis.

 

Option B. Proteus: Proteus species are gram-negative bacilli. They can cause a variety of infections, including urinary tract infections and, less commonly, prostatitis. A characteristic of Proteus infections is the production of urease, which splits urea into ammonia and leads to an alkaline urine that can cause struvite stone formation.

 

Option C. Streptococcus Agalactiae: Also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), Streptococcus agalactiae is a gram-positive coccus. While it's a leading cause of neonatal infections, it's an infrequent cause of urinary tract infections in adults and an even rarer cause of prostatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Escherichia coli (E. coli) is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis, accounting for the majority of cases and is frequently found in urinary tract infections.

questions.text: Based on the symptoms reported by the patient, what could be the possible diagnosis for a 30-year-old man who has been experiencing recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for the past four years? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fistula in ano

 

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract or channel that develops between the anal canal and the skin around the anus.
  • It is usually caused by an infected anal gland or abscess that fails to heal.
  • The symptoms of a fistula in ano may include pain, swelling, discharge of pus or blood, and recurrent abscesses around the anus.
  • Diagnosis of a fistula in ano is typically made by a physical examination and medical history review.
  • Imaging studies such as MRI or ultrasound may also be used to determine the extent and location of the fistula.
  • Given the patient's chronic history of recurrent discharge and pain around the anus for four years, a fistula in ano is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pilonidal sinus: A pilonidal sinus is a small cyst or abscess that occurs in the cleft at the top of the natal cleft. It often contains hair and skin debris. Common symptoms include pain, redness, and swelling in the area of the buttocks crease, and sometimes it can release pus. Given that the patient's symptoms are around the anus and involve recurrent discharge and pain for several years, a pilonidal sinus, which primarily occurs in the cleft of the buttocks, is less likely.

 

Option B. Carbuncle: A carbuncle is an infective gangrene seen on the back or chest wall. Carbuncles can lead to the formation of an abscess, and symptoms might include a lump filled with pus, which might weep or ooze. While carbuncles can form on any part of the body, their acute and more widespread nature differs from the chronic, recurrent discharge around the anus described by the patient.

 

Option C. Boil: A boil, or furuncle, is a skin infection that starts in a hair follicle or oil gland. It typically starts as a reddened and tender area, which becomes hard and then softens as it fills with pus. Boils can occur anywhere on the body, but they're more common on the face, neck, armpits, buttocks, and thighs. Again, given the chronic and recurrent nature of the patient's symptoms specifically around the anus, a singular boil wouldn't match this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract that typically develops between the anal canal and the perianal skin, usually due to a previously untreated or inadequately treated abscess.
  • The chronic and recurrent nature of symptoms like discharge and pain around the anus is a hallmark of this condition.

questions.text: Saturnine gout is seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lead poisoning

 

Saturnine Gout:

 

  • Description: Saturnine gout is a type of gout caused by chronic lead intoxication. This can result from occult or occupational exposure to lead, or from the ingestion of moonshine (illegally produced alcohol that may contain lead contaminants).
  • Incidence: Accounts for less than 5% of gout cases.
  • Mechanism: Lead induces tubulointerstitial renal damage, which impairs the kidneys' ability to excrete uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia (excessive uric acid in the blood).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Similar to primary gout, but with a predilection for affecting the knee more than the first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe).
    • Hyperuricemia in Saturnine gout exceeds the reduction in glomerular filtration rate (GFR), meaning the high uric acid levels are disproportionate to the kidney's filtration capacity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cadmium poisoning: Symptoms: Kidney damage, osteomalacia (bone softening), and respiratory issues.

 

Option C. Beryllium poisoning: Symptoms: Respiratory problems, chronic beryllium disease (CBD), and lung cancer.

 

Option D. Mercury poisoning: Symptoms: Neurological and behavioral disorders, kidney damage, and gastrointestinal disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Saturnine gout is a specific type of gout caused by chronic lead poisoning, characterized by hyperuricemia and tubulointerstitial renal damage.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effect is least likely to be associated with the use of amiodarone? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gynecomastia

 

Among the options given, gynecomastia is the least likely to be associated with the use of amiodarone. Hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, and pulmonary fibrosis are all recognized adverse effects of amiodarone, while gynecomastia is not typically linked to its use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Amiodarone can cause both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism due to its high iodine content and its effect on thyroid hormone synthesis and metabolism.

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: As mentioned above, hyperthyroidism is also a known side effect of amiodarone, along with hypothyroidism.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Fibrosis: Pulmonary fibrosis is a well-known and potentially serious side effect of amiodarone, likely due to its toxic effects on lung tissue and prolonged half-life.

 

Adverse Effects of Amiodarone can be remembered as:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gynecomastia is typically associated with drugs that affect hormonal balance. Drugs causing gynecomastia includes:

 

DI:        DIgoxin

S:         Spironolactone

C:         Cimetidine

O:        Oestrogens

choices.text: Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease
Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn's disease and transmural involvement is seen in ulcerative colitis
Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic predisposition
Crohn's disease is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment

questions.text: Mark the correct statement regarding inflammatory bowel disease (IBD): (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease

 

Crohn's disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to the anus. It is characterized by a patchy distribution of inflammation, which is often transmural (affecting the entire thickness of the bowel wall). Skeletions, also known as skip lesions, are a hallmark feature of Crohn's disease, where areas of inflamed tissue are interspersed with healthy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn's disease and transmural involvement is seen in ulcerative colitis: This statement is incorrect. Crohn's disease typically involves transmural inflammation, meaning it affects all layers of the bowel wall. On the other hand, ulcerative colitis is characterized by inflammation that is limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon and rectum.

 

Option C. Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic predisposition: While there are genetic factors associated with IBD, such as mutations in the NOD2/CARD15 gene linked to Crohn's disease, the overall genetic predisposition is not considered strong. Environmental factors play a more significant role in the development of IBD.

 

Option D. Crohn's disease is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment: This statement is incorrect. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract and is not curable by surgical resection. Surgery can help manage symptoms and complications but does not cure the disease. Ulcerative colitis, however, can be cured by surgical removal of the colon and rectum (total proctocolectomy).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Skepletions (skip lesions) are a characteristic feature of Crohn's disease, distinguishing it from ulcerative colitis

choices.text: A - Cortisol B - Aldosterone C - Androgens D - Epinephrine
A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine
A - Epinephrine B - Cortisol C - Aldosterone D - Androgens
A - Aldosterone B - Epinephrine C - Androgens D - Cortisol

questions.text: Which hormones are produced from these zones? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine

 

Explanation:

 

The adrenal gland, located on top of the kidneys, consists of the adrenal cortex and the adrenal medulla. The cortex is further divided into three zones: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis. These zones are responsible for producing different types of hormones, remembered by the mnemonic "GFR."

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa (A): This outermost layer is responsible for producing mineralocorticoids, the most important being Aldosterone. Aldosterone plays a critical role in regulating sodium and potassium balance in the body.
  • Zona Fasciculata (B): The middle layer produces glucocorticoids, primarily Cortisol. Cortisol is involved in stress response, metabolism regulation, and immune function.
  • Zona Reticularis (C): The innermost cortical layer produces androgens, specifically DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone), which is a precursor to sex steroids like testosterone and estrogen.
  • Adrenal Medulla (D): The medulla produces catecholamines, primarily Epinephrine (adrenaline), which is crucial for the fight-or-flight response.

 

Educational Objective:


The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones—zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis—which produce aldosterone, cortisol, and androgens, respectively. The adrenal medulla produces catecholamines, primarily epinephrine

choices.text: 1-5% of the population can have epileptiform discharges.
Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy.
Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves.

questions.text: True about electroencephalogram (EEG) is all except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.

 

Electroencephalography (EEG) is a key diagnostic tool in the evaluation of neurological conditions, particularly epilepsy. However, it is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures. A patient can have seizures even if their EEG results are normal. An abnormal EEG can provide reassurance of a diagnosis of epilepsy when the clinical context supports it, but a normal EEG does not rule out epilepsy or seizures. Therefore, making an EEG mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1-5% of the population can have epileptiform discharges: This statement is correct. Epileptiform discharges can be present in a small percentage of the general population without necessarily indicating that the individual has epilepsy.

 

Option B. Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy: This statement is correct. Scalp EEG can indeed help localize the origin of epileptic activity, including frontal lobe epilepsy, although it might not always be definitive.

 

Option D. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves: This statement is correct. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) and other forms of encephalopathy can show triphasic waves and slow wave patterns on an EEG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EEG is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures as patients can have seizures even with a normal EEG.

questions.text: A patient develops acute confusion and disorientation shortly after undergoing surgical intervention for a malignant tumor. Which of the following medications is typically the first-line treatment for this condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Haloperidol

 

The patient is experiencing acute confusion and disorientation following surgery, which suggests the development of delirium. Delirium is a common postoperative complication, especially in older adults or those with significant medical conditions. The first-line treatment for delirium, particularly when it is accompanied by psychotic symptoms or severe agitation, is antipsychotic medication. Haloperidol is a traditional antipsychotic that is commonly used in this situation due to its efficacy in controlling these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lorazepam: Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine, which is not typically used as a first-line treatment for delirium. It is more appropriate in the treatment of delirium tremens, which is a specific type of delirium associated with alcohol withdrawal. In cases of delirium not related to alcohol withdrawal, lorazepam can actually worsen the confusion.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Olanzapine is another antipsychotic that can be used to treat delirium, but it is not considered the first-line treatment as Haloperidol is more commonly preferred in acute cases.

 

Option D. Risperidone: Risperidone is also an antipsychotic that can be used in the management of delirium, but similar to Olanzapine, Haloperidol is generally preferred as the first-line option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Haloperidol is the first-line treatment for delirium, especially when the patient exhibits significant agitation or psychotic symptoms following surgery.

questions.text: An adult presented with pallor, fatigue and reduced work capacity.  His investigations revealed low RBC count, low hemoglobin, MCV 70fL and MCH24pg. which of the following is the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by low RBC count, low hemoglobin, and microcytic hypochromic indices (MCV < 80 fl and MCH < 27 pg). The patient’s symptoms of pallor, fatigue, and reduced work capacity are typical of anemia. The lab findings of MCV 70 fl (microcytic) and MCH 24 pg (hypochromic) are consistent with iron deficiency anemia, the most common type of anemia worldwide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folate deficiency: Causes macrocytic anemia (MCV > 100 fl), which is not consistent with the patient's lab results.

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease: Typically presents with normocytic or slightly microcytic anemia. However, iron deficiency anemia is more common and fits better with the lab findings.

 

Option C. Anemia due to renal failure: Usually presents with normocytic anemia, where the MCV is within the normal range (80-100 fl), not microcytic.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Inherited defect in PIG-A
Deficiency of CD 55 and CD 59

questions.text: Which of the following is true about paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Deficiency of CD 55 and CD 59

 

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is characterized by a deficiency in the proteins CD55 and CD59, which normally protect red blood cells from immune attack. This deficiency is caused by a mutation in the PIG-A gene on the X chromosome, which is acquired (not inherited) and results in the failure to attach these protective proteins to the cell membrane. Without these proteins, red blood cells become susceptible to destruction by the complement system, a part of the immune system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inherited defect in PIG-A: This statement is incorrect. The defect in the PIG-A gene associated with PNH is acquired, not inherited.

 

Option B. Extravascular hemolysis: PNH primarily causes intravascular hemolysis, not extravascular. This is because the unregulated activation of the complement system leads to the lysis of red blood cells within the circulatory system.

 

Option D. Microcytic anemia: PNH typically results in normocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia. The anemia in PNH is due to the destruction of red blood cells by the complement system, which affects cells of normal size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The true hallmark of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is the deficiency of CD55 and CD59 on the surface of blood cells, leading to increased vulnerability to lysis by the complement system and resulting in intravascular hemolysis. This understanding is critical for the correct diagnosis and management of PNH.

 

Reference - Harrison/PNH/Chapter 100

choices.text: Glucose tolerance test

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options is non-essential in the evaluation of mosaic Turner syndrome? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti-nuclear antibodies

 

Out of the provided choices, the presence of anti-nuclear antibodies is not a necessary factor when investigating mosaic Turner syndrome.

 

Mosaic Turner syndrome is non-hereditary in nature. It emerges from a chance incident during the phase of cell division in the initial stages of fetal development in the impacted individual. Consequently, a portion of an individual's cells retain the standard two sex chromosomes, whereas another set of cells possess just a single X chromosome copy.

 

Features of Turner Syndrome:

 

 

Other options:

 

 

Option B. Glucose Tolerance Test: Important for detecting glucose intolerance or diabetes, which is common in Turner syndrome.

 

Option C. Audiometry: Used to assess hearing loss, which is more prevalent in individuals with Turner syndrome.

 

Option D. Echocardiography: Critical for evaluating congenital heart defects, such as coarctation of the aorta or bicuspid aortic valve, which are common in Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While glucose tolerance testing, audiometry, and echocardiography are essential in the evaluation of Turner syndrome, testing for anti-nuclear antibodies is not necessary unless there is a clinical suspicion of an associated autoimmune disorder.

questions.text: In a patient with suspected endocrine dysfunction, which hormone primarily acts through the signaling pathway shown in the diagram below, potentially contributing to the patient's condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leptin

 

The provided image depicts the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, known for its association with tyrosine kinase receptors. Within this pathway, leptin operates as one of the hormones involved. Leptin binds to its receptor, activating the JAK-STAT signaling cascade. This pathway is crucial for regulating energy balance and body weight, and its dysfunction can lead to endocrine and metabolic disorders. Leptin's role in this pathway highlights its importance in physiological processes and potential involvement in the patient's endocrine dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcitonin: Calcitonin primarily uses a different signaling mechanism involving G-protein-coupled receptors, not the JAK-STAT pathway.

 

Option C. Vasopressin: Vasopressin operates through G-protein-coupled receptors, particularly influencing water reabsorption in the kidneys, and does not utilize the JAK-STAT signaling pathway.

 

Option D. Aldosterone: Aldosterone acts mainly through mineralocorticoid receptors, influencing sodium and potassium balance in the kidneys, and is not involved in the JAK-STAT signaling pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Hamman sign is seen in: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Pneumomediastinum

 

Hamman sign, also known as Hamman's mediastinal crunch, is a crunching, rasping sound, synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium in cases of pneumomediastinum. This sign is caused by air in the mediastinum, which is the central compartment of the thoracic cavity. The presence of air in this area leads to a characteristic sound as the heart beats, which can be heard on auscultation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Pneumoperitoneum: Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air within the peritoneal cavity, usually due to gastrointestinal perforation. Clinical signs include guarding, rigidity, and air under the diaphragm visible on imaging. Hamman sign is not associated with pneumoperitoneum.

 

Option B. Pneumopericardium: This condition involves air within the pericardial cavity surrounding the heart. While it can cause similar auscultatory findings, it does not specifically present with Hamman sign.

 

Option D. Hydropneumothorax: This condition involves both air and fluid in the pleural space. A significant clinical finding here is straight-line dullness on percussion, not Hamman sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hamman sign, or Hamman's crunch, is a specific clinical sign heard in cases of pneumomediastinum, characterized by a crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat due to the presence of air in the mediastinum.

questions.text: Which of the following type of cataract is seen in ocular blunt trauma?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rosette cataract

 

A rosette cataract, also known as a traumatic cataract, is a specific type of cataract that can occur as a result of ocular blunt trauma. When the eye experiences blunt trauma, such as a direct blow or impact, it can cause disruption or damage to the lens fibers, leading to the formation of a characteristic star-shaped opacity within the lens.

 

The term "rosette" refers to the appearance of the cataract, which resembles a flower-like pattern with radiating spokes or lines extending from a central point.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxic cataract: This type of cataract is caused by exposure to toxic substances, such as certain medications, chemicals, or radiation.

 

Option B. Metabolic cataract: Metabolic cataracts develop due to systemic metabolic disorders, such as diabetes or galactosemia, which affect the metabolism of the lens proteins.

 

Option D. Nuclear cataract: Nuclear cataract affects the central portion of the lens (nucleus) and is associated with aging. It causes gradual clouding and yellowing of the lens nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rosette cataract is commonly seen in ocular blunt trauma.

questions.text: Based on the image, a 60-year-old male patient with diabetes presents with progressive skin lesions. What could be the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

 

The image above displays a central rodent ulcer, which indicates basal cell carcinoma. This malignant tumor exhibits characteristics of slow local invasion and mainly affects the pilosebaceous skin.

 

Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC):

 

  • The most significant predisposing factor for basal cell carcinoma is exposure to ultraviolet radiation. Other risk factors include ionizing radiation, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and arsenic exposure.
  • Basal cell carcinoma predominantly affects middle-aged or elderly men with a history of excessive sun exposure, often among individuals with white skin, aged between 40 to 80 years.

 

Morphologically, basal cell carcinoma can be of 2 types:

 

1. Localized types: These are more common and include:

 

  • Nodular and nodulocystic BCC: Representing the majority of cases, these appear as pearly, waxy nodules with rolled borders and sometimes central ulceration or depression, known as umbilication.

 

 

  • Pigmented BCC: These are similar to nodular BCC but contain melanin, giving them a darker appearance.
  • Nevoid BCC: This type is rarer and can resemble benign moles.

 

2. Generalized types: These are less common and can be more challenging to treat due to their growth patterns:

 

  • Superficial multifocal and spreading BCC: Often appearing as scaly, erythematous patches that can be mistaken for eczema or psoriasis.
  • Infiltrative BCC: These grow more aggressively and can invade deeper tissues.
  • Cicatrizing (or sclerosing) BCC: This type can cause scarring as it grows.

 

While nodular BCC is the most common form, it is important for medical practitioners to recognize the less common types due to their growth patterns and potential for tissue destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

 

  • It typically presents as a firm, red nodule or a flat sore with a scaly crust as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • While it's possible for diabetic patients to develop SCC, the description provided fits BCC more closely.

 

Option C. Melasma

 

  • It is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • It is usually seen on the face.
  • It is more common in women, especially during pregnancy, and is not typically associated with progressive lesions.

 

Option D. Discoid lupus erythematosus

 

  • It often presents as a chronic rash with red, inflamed, and scaly patches that can cause scarring, usually on the face, ears, and scalp, as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • It is an autoimmune condition and not directly linked to diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an elderly patient, progressive pearly or waxy skin lesions, especially if located on sun-exposed areas, are likely indicative of basal cell carcinoma.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page no 4.15, 51.3, 88.10-12, 141.1-16

Robbins basic pathology 10th edition page no 1148

Bailey & Loves short practice of surgery 27th edition Page no 599, 604-6011

questions.text: Fallen fragment sign is characteristic of:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Simple bone cyst

 

SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Also known as unicameral bone cyst.
  • It affects children in the first and second decade.
  • The lesions are most active during skeletal growth and usually heal spontaneously at maturity.
  • They arise in the metaphysis and are central or medullary.
  • The proximal humerus and proximal femur are common sites.
  • It is not a tumor.
  • The condition is usually asymptomatic, unless discovered after a pathological fracture or as an incidental finding on X-ray.
  • An SBC contains serous or serosanguinous fluid.
  • Plain radiographs reveal a centrally located, purely lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline.
  • Occasionally (20%), a thinned cortical fragment fractures and falls into the base of the lesion confirming its empty cystic nature. This, ‘Fallen Fragment’ sign, is pathognomonic of a unicameral bone cyst.
  • Bone fragment may also hinge around and move with fluid – ‘Trap Door sign’
  • Unicameral bone cysts are classified as active when they are within 1 cm of the physis and latent when they are closer to the diaphysis.
  • Small, asymptomatic lesions in the upper extremities can be treated with observation with serial plain radiographs.
  • Larger lesions (lesions at risk for pathological fracture), symptomatic lesions, and lesions in the lower extremities are usually are treated with curettage (with or without bone grafting or internal fixation) or aspiration and injection (often using steroids, bone marrow aspirate, demineralized bone matrix, or sclerosant).

 

 

A. Unicameral or simple bone cyst; B. Fallen fragment (leaf) sign

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aneurysmal bone cyst. Aneurysmal bone cysts are locally destructive, blood-filled reactive lesions of bone and are not considered to be true neoplasms. Most commonly involves the lower limbs. Vertebral lesions (15-20%) are located in the posterior elements.

 

 

Radiographs reveal an expansile lytic lesion that elevates the periosteum, but remains contained by a thin shell of cortical bone. It can have well-defined margins or a permeative appearance that mimics a malignancy. It is most often eccentrically located in the metaphysis. When differentiating between a unicameral and aneurysmal bone cyst using MRI, the presence of a double-density fluid level and intralesional septations usually indicates an aneurysmal bone cyst.

 

 

Double-density fluid level on MRI

 

Aneurysmal bone cysts are treated with extended curettage and grafting. Lesions in the spine or pelvis can be treated with preoperative embolization to minimize surgical blood loss. Low-dose irradiation is an effective method of treatment, often associated with rapid ossification; however, it is not used routinely because of the potential for malignant transformation.

 

Option C. Giant cell tumor. They typically occur in 20-40 years old patients. There is a slight female predominance. The most common location is the distal femur, followed by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation. Although these tumors are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT. Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone. Although rare in skeletally immature patients, giant cell tumors arise in the metaphysis in this age group. Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex; however, intraarticular extension is rare because the subchondral bone usually remains intact.

 

 

Treatment includes extended curettage and bone grafting; excision and replacement by vascularized bone graft/prosthetic replacement.

 

Option D. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fallen fragment sign is seen in simple (unicameral) bone cyst. It is a thinned cortical fragment that fractures and falls into the base of the lesion, confirming its empty cystic nature

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metoprolol

 

Metoprolol, specifically the succinate formulation, is a beta-blocker that has been shown to reduce mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). Beta-blockers like metoprolol, bisoprolol, and carvedilol improve survival, reduce hospitalizations, and improve symptoms in heart failure patients.

 

Note - Drugs that reduce mortality in patients with heart failure, in a recommended order of use:

 

  1. First Line Drug: ACE inhibitors helps to relax blood vessels and improve blood flow, thereby decreasing the heart's workload.
  2. Second Line Drug: Beta blockers worked by slowing the heart rate and reducing blood pressure, which decreases the heart's demand for oxygen.
  3. Third Line Drug: Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists, such as spironolactone helps to remove excess sodium and water from the body, relieving pressure on the heart while preserving potassium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Furosemide: A loop diuretic that provides symptomatic relief by reducing fluid overload but does not reduce mortality in heart failure patients.

 

Option C. Prazosin: An alpha-blocker used for hypertension but not shown to reduce mortality in heart failure.

 

Option D. Torsemide: Another loop diuretic similar to furosemide, effective for symptomatic relief but not for reducing mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-blockers, such as metoprolol succinate, are essential in reducing mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction

 

Note –

 

Drugs That Reduce Mortality in Heart Failure

 

  1. ARNIs (Angiotensin Receptor-Neprilysin Inhibitors):
    • Examples: Sacubitril/Valsartan
    • Currently the first-line treatment, considered superior to ACE inhibitors and ARBs when available.
       
  2. ACE Inhibitors (Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme inhibitors) and ARBs (Angiotensin II Receptor Blockers):
    • Considered equally effective in efficacy; used when ARNIs are not available.
       
  3. Beta Blockers:
    • Specific agents highlighted: Metoprolol, Bisoprolol, and Carvedilol.
       
  4. MRS (Mineralocorticoid Receptor Antagonists):
    • Examples: Spironolactone and Eplerenone.
       
  5. SGLT2 Inhibitors (Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter 2 inhibitors):
    • Emerging class of drugs also showing benefits in heart failure management.
       
  6. Hydralazine and Isosorbide Dinitrate (HISDN):
    • Noted specifically for proven benefits in African American patients with heart failure.

 

Drugs with No Impact on Mortality

 

  1. Diuretics:
    • Including loop and thiazide diuretics, noted to not improve survival but are used primarily for symptom management and fluid regulation.
       
  2. Calcium Channel Blockers and Nitrates:
    • Mentioned as not improving survival in heart failure, particularly in patients with reduced ejection fraction.

questions.text: Lagophthalmos is caused by defect in: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 7th cranial nerve

 

Lagophthalmos is the inability to close the eye completely. This condition is caused by a defect in the 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve). The facial nerve innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle, which is responsible for closing the eyelid. When this nerve is damaged or dysfunctional, it leads to weakness or paralysis of the orbicularis oculi, resulting in incomplete eyelid closure.

 

 

Note - It's important to distinguish between "lagophthalmos" (inability to close the eye) and "lid lag" (where the eyelid doesn't follow the eyeball's movement properly), as both involve "lag" but refer to different phenomena and are caused by different underlying issues.

 

Lid Lag occurs when the eyelid fails to follow the downward movement of the eyeball when shifting from an upward gaze to a straight or downward gaze. This condition is noticeable in thyroid eye disease and is associated with von Graefe's sign.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd cranial nerve: The oculomotor nerve innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is responsible for raising the upper eyelid. A defect in this nerve would cause ptosis (drooping eyelid) rather than lagophthalmos.

 

Option B. 4th cranial nerve: The trochlear nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which is involved in eye movement. It is not directly related to eyelid function.

 

Option C. 6th cranial nerve: The abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for lateral eye movement. It does not control eyelid function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lagophthalmos is caused by a defect in the 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve), which innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle responsible for eyelid closure

choices.text: Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin
Intravenous fluids with S.C. regular insulin
Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. She is non-compliant with medication and appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed a blood sugar value of 500 mg/dL and the presence of ketone bodies. What is the next best step in management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

 

In a patient presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the immediate management involves FLIP Therapy (fluid resuscitation, insulin therapy and Potassium management). This patient's blood glucose is significantly elevated, and the presence of ketones indicates DKA, which is a medical emergency.

 

1. Fluids: The initial step is to administer intravenous (IV) fluids to correct dehydration and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status. The typical approach involves giving isotonic saline (0.9% sodium chloride) at a rate of 10-20 mL/kg/hr (2-3L) for the first 2-3 hours. This helps to correct hypovolemia, improve perfusion, and begin to lower blood glucose levels.

 

Criteria for fluid management: After the initial two to three hours of treatment, switch from initial fluids (typically normal saline) to half normal saline for ongoing maintenance. If capillary blood glucose (CBG) drops below 300 mg/dL, and specifically if it falls below 250 mg/dL, add 5% dextrose water to the regimen. The purpose of adding dextrose is to maintain a target CBG range of 200 to 300 mg/dL. This range helps prevent hypoglycemia, which is a critical concern in the management process.

 

2. Insulin: Insulin therapy is crucial to halt ketogenesis and reduce blood glucose levels. After 1 hr of fluid start insulin. The recommended protocol for DKA involves IV regular insulin because of its rapid onset and short duration of action. The insulin regimen follows a fixed dose insulin infusion (FDII) approach. This helps to normalize blood glucose and ketone levels efficiently.

 

First option: Continuous infusion at 0.15 units/kg/hour.

 

Second option (more commonly used): Administer a 0.1 units/kg bolus, followed by a 0.1 units/kg/hour infusion.

 

IV regular insulin is preferred over subcutaneous (SC) insulin in emergency settings like DKA due to its predictable absorption and ability to be titrated easily based on frequent blood glucose monitoring.

 

Adjustments Based on Blood Glucose Levels: Monitor capillary blood glucose (CBG). If CBG drops below 300 mg/dL, reduce the insulin infusion to half the dose (0.05 units/kg/hour).

 

Criteria for Stopping Insulin Infusion: Insulin infusion can be stopped ONLY when the patient tolerates oral feeds without vomiting or abdominal pain. Other criteria include resolution of ketoacidosis, negative or trace positive plasma ketones, and an anion gap less than 12, pH more than 7.3 and serum bicarbonate more than 18. Transition to subcutaneous insulin upon meeting these criteria.

 

Potassium Management: Potassium addition is tailored based on serum potassium levels. When serum potassium levels are within a normal range, add approximately 40 milliequivalents of potassium chloride (KCL) per liter of IV fluid administered. This ensures adequate potassium levels to prevent hypokalemia.

 

Monitoring

 

  • If serum potassium is below 3.3, administer IV potassium chloride (KCL) before insulin to prevent hypokalemia-induced arrhythmias.
  • If serum potassium is between 3.3 and 5.2, administer insulin and KCL together.
  • If serum potassium exceeds 5.3 & above, administer insulin without KCL and monitor serum potassium closely.

 

Treatment Goals and Precautions:

 

  • Aim for a target CBG of 200 to 300 mg/dL to avoid hypoglycemia.
  • The common causes of death in patients with DKA, particularly during the treatment phase – 
    • Cerebral edema (MC) may occur due to a rapid decrease in blood glucose levels, which can lead to an osmotic shift. This shift causes fluids to move from the extracellular fluid (ECF) to the intracellular fluid (ICF), resulting in swelling of the brain tissue.
    • 2nd MC cause is Potassium Disorder esp. Hypokalemia, this can result in ventricular arrythmias.
    • Other causes include ARDS, patients can initially develop acute kidney injury (pre-renal), later if severe, leads to ATN (Acute tubular necrosis) due to hypoperfusion of kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin: Long-acting insulin is not suitable for acute management due to its prolonged action and delayed onset, making it inappropriate for rapid correction of hyperglycemia and ketonemia.

 

Option B. Intravenous fluids with S.C. regular insulin: While regular insulin is appropriate, the subcutaneous route is less effective in severe DKA where IV administration allows for better control and titration.

 

Option C. Intravenous insulin I.V. long-acting insulin: Long-acting insulin is never administered IV due to the risk of prolonged hypoglycemia and lack of titratability. It is also not designed for acute management settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the initial steps involve aggressive IV fluid resuscitation followed by IV regular insulin to rapidly lower blood glucose and resolve ketosis.

choices.text: It is the most common type of squint.
Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio.
It is associated with high myopia.
Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding accommodative esotropia? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is associated with high myopia.

 

Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of esotropia and is associated with hypermetropia (farsightedness), not myopia (nearsightedness). The condition often presents in children around 2 to 3 years of age and is characterized by an inward turning of the eyes that is related to the effort of focusing (accommodation).

 

Types:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the most common type of squint: True. Accommodative esotropia is indeed the most common type of esotropia seen in children. This type of squint is related to the effort of focusing (accommodation) and is associated with farsightedness (hypermetropia).

 

Option B. Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio: True. Miotics can be used to manage accommodative esotropia associated with a high AC/A ratio. Miotics reduce the need for accommodation, thereby reducing the associated esotropia.

 

Option D. Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles: True. The refractive type of accommodative esotropia can be fully corrected by using spectacles that correct the hypermetropia. These spectacles reduce the accommodative effort, thereby correcting the esotropia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Accommodative esotropia, the most common type of squint, is associated with high hypermetropia and can often be fully corrected by spectacles. It is not associated with high myopia. Different treatment strategies, including the use of spectacles and bifocals, depend on the specific type and underlying cause of the esotropia.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ascaris lumbricoides

 

The roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

 

They are large cylindrical worms with tapered ends

 

The anterior end is more pointed than the posterior.

 

They are pale pink or flesh colored when freshly passed in stools, but become white outside the body.

 

The mouth at the anterior end has three finely toothed lips, one dorsal and two ventrolateral

 

Habitat - Small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum).

 

Natural host – Man

 

Infective form – embryonated eggs containing infective rhabditiform larvae

 

Mode of transmission – feco-oral route

 

Disease caused by A. lumbricoides is called as ascariasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercoralis: Causes strongyloidiasis, and the worms are much smaller and typically not as robust as those shown in the image.

 

Option B. Enterobius vermicularis: Causes enterobiasis or pinworm infection. The worms are much smaller and thinner, typically only a few millimeters long.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection. The worms are also smaller and have a characteristic hook shape at one end.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ascaris lumbricoides is a large, cylindrical nematode parasite found in the human intestine, easily identifiable by its size, tapered ends, and characteristic pink to white color transition. The disease it causes, ascariasis, is transmitted via the fecal-oral route.

questions.text: A patient with suspected tuberculosis underwent CBNAAT testing and is started on HRZE. CBNAAT is helpful for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTB + Rifampicin resistance

 

Explanation

 

Cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test (CBNAAT) is a rapid molecular test for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and resistance to rifampicin (RIF).

 

It is highly effective for diagnosing tuberculosis and determining rifampicin resistance by detecting mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance. This allows for quick initiation of appropriate therapy, especially important in cases of drug-resistant TB

 

  • MTB Detection: CBNAAT can confirm the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Rifampicin Resistance: By identifying rpoB gene mutations, CBNAAT can detect rifampicin resistance, which is a critical factor in managing and treating TB.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB): While CBNAAT detects MTB, it also provides crucial information about rifampicin resistance, making option B more accurate.

 

Option C. MTB + Isoniazid resistance: CBNAAT does not detect isoniazid resistance directly.

 

Option D. MTB + Ethambutol and Rifampicin: CBNAAT does not provide information about ethambutol resistance.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

CBNAAT is a rapid and effective test for detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene.

choices.text: Toxoplasma gondii

questions.text: Identify the organism from the lifecycle shown in the image given below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoplasma gondii

 

The given image shows the lifecycle of Toxoplasma gondii.

 

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that causes toxoplasmosis.

 

Definitive hosts - Members of Felidae (domestic cats and their relatives). The enteric cycle occurs in definitive hosts.

 

Intermediate hosts in nature (including birds and rodents). Exoenteric cycle occurs in intermediate hosts such as humans, mice, rats, etc.

 

Life cycle of toxoplasma gondii

 

  1. Unsporulated oocysts are shed in the cat’s feces. Although oocysts are usually only shed for 1–3 weeks, large numbers may be shed.
  2. Oocysts take 1–5 days to sporulate in the environment and become infective. Intermediate hosts in nature (including birds and rodents) become infected after ingesting soil, water or plant material contaminated with oocysts.
  3. Oocysts transform into tachyzoites shortly after ingestion. These tachyzoites localize in neural and muscle tissue and develop into tissue cyst bradyzoites.
  4. Cats become infected after consuming intermediate hosts harboring tissue cysts. Cats may also become infected directly by ingestion of sporulated oocysts.
  5. Animals bred for human consumption and wild game may also become infected with tissue cysts after ingestion of sporulated oocysts in the environment.

 

Humans can become infected by any of several routes:

 

  • Eating undercooked meat of animals harboring tissue cysts
  • Consuming food or water contaminated with cat feces or by contaminated environmental samples (such as fecal-contaminated soil or changing the litter box of a pet cat).
  • Blood transfusion or organ transplantation.
  • Transplacentally from mother to fetus.
  • In the human host, the parasites form tissue cysts, most commonly in skeletal muscle, myocardium, brain, and eyes; these cysts may remain throughout the life of the host.

 

 

Diagnosis is usually achieved by serology, although tissue cysts may be observed in stained biopsy specimens.

 

Diagnosis of congenital infections can be achieved by detecting T. gondii DNA in amniotic fluid using molecular methods such as PCR

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Cystoisospora: Causes isosporiasis, primarily affecting the gastrointestinal tract. Its lifecycle involves humans as the definitive host.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium: Causes cryptosporidiosis, an intestinal illness. The lifecycle involves direct fecal-oral transmission.

 

Option C. Plasmodium knowlesi: Causes malaria, with a lifecycle involving mosquitoes as vectors and humans as host.

 

Educational Objective

 

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite with a complex lifecycle involving cats as definitive hosts and various animals, including humans, as intermediate hosts. The lifecycle stages, including oocysts and tissue cysts, are crucial for transmission and infection.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract. The patient's parents report that he has had multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis. Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test results show an abnormal pattern. What is the primary suspicion based on these findings? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract, along with a history of multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis in a young child, strongly suggests a primary immunodeficiency disorder. The abnormal dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test result further supports the diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD).

 

CGD is a rare inherited disorder characterized by defective oxygen-dependent killing of microorganisms by phagocytic cells, such as neutrophils and macrophages. This defect is caused by mutations in the genes encoding components of the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex, which is responsible for generating reactive oxygen species (ROS) necessary for microbial killing. The inability to produce sufficient ROS leads to recurrent infections, especially with catalase-positive organisms.

 

The DHR test is a flow cytometry-based assay that measures the production of ROS by neutrophils after stimulation. An abnormal DHR test result, as seen in this patient, is consistent with the diagnosis of CGD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID) is a group of disorders characterized by defects in both cellular and humoral immunity.

 

X-linked SCID is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder characterized by chronic diarrhea, periodic respiratory infection, and acquired maternal T cell-mediated GVHD.
